III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section
Description
1

(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following: (a) Routine
and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency started a youth on a new medication without notifying
their parents or foster care. Neither party was privy to the medical
appointment set to discuss prescribed medication. The facility staff
could not provide any information on what the new medication
was, what it was for, or possible reactions.
Investigation Interviews
On 7/30/2025 Residential Manager 1 (RM 1) was interviewed at
Methodist by DCWL Consultant 2. RM 1 reported Mother was
called during the medication review for Youth A but did not
answer. He said a voice message was left. He denied that the
medication is a psychotropic medication and stated it is prescribed
for enuresis. He further reported that the medication instructions
were reviewed with the Mother when Youth A was picked up for
an overnight visit. He lastly confirmed that the foster care worker
was aware of the prescribed medication.
On 08/04/2025 and 08/28/2025 telephone calls were made to
Complainant without success. A voicemail message was left
requesting a return call.
On 08/04/2025 an email was sent to Foster Care Worker (FCW)
advising of investigation. A request was made to respond with
any concerns. To date no response has been received.
On 08/05/2025 an in-person interview was completed with
Residential Manager 2 (RM 2) at Methodist, Area Manager was
also present. RM 2 reported that she was advised by Physician
that both Mother and FCW were contacted to discuss the
prescribed medication. Neither were available and voicemail
messages were left. RM 2 indicated that the medication was not
to treat psychotropic issues and is for Enuresis. RM 2 provided
information for prescribing physician for additional follow-up.
On 08/05/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Youth
A at Methodist with Area Manager present. Youth A was unable
to advise of all prescribed medication, but confirmed he was
started on a new medication to help with him wetting the bed at
night.
2

On 08/05/2025 an in-person interview was completed with
Supervisor at Methodist with Area Manager present. Supervisor
confirmed that Youth A was recently prescribed a new medication
to treat his Enuresis. She reported that when Mother arrived to
pick up youth and reviewed and signed the chain of custody form,
she indicated that she was not aware of the new psych medication
and did not consent to the medication.
On 08/05/2025 an in-person interview was completed with
Therapist at Methodist with Area Manager present. She
confirmed that she was present when Mother returned Youth A to
the campus. She denied any knowledge regarding the medication
but noted that Mother was upset and stated that she did not
consent to the psych meds that were prescribed for her son.
Therapist also advised that Mother had stated that she did not
dispense the meds to Youth A during his visit.
On 08/26/2025 a telephone call was made to Physician without
success. On 09/06/2025 a return call was received from
Physician. She confirmed that the prescribed medication is not a
psychotropic med and is for the treatment of Enuresis. She
reported that she made attempts to contact Mother and FCW to
discuss the medication without success. She further reported that
she is not required to have parental consent to prescribe
Desmopressin (DDAVP) and stated that she has confirmed that
with the State of Michigan Licensing Regulatory department.
Physician also advised that she has since had contact with Mother
via telephone and clarified for her that the medication is not a
psychotropic medication. Physician reported that mother
indicated she still does not want Youth A to take the medication
and that agency staff can just wake him up at night during their
15-minute checks. Physician noted that the medication has been
discontinued for Youth A as of 9/03/2025 based on the mothers
advocacy for not taking the medication.
Documentation Reviewed
Methodist Children’s Home Medication Policy – There are two
main categories of medication: Prescription and non-prescription
(over the counter medications). Prescription medication must be
prescribed by a person licensed to do so by the Department of
Licensing and Regulation (Physician, Dentist, Nurse, Ect.).
All medication, including over-the-counter medication, must be
prescribed or directions given for use by a licensed medical
professional. MCHS has a list of over the counter medications
approved by the consulting pediatrician that can be given with the
3

prescribed medications. This list has specific directions for use
and precautions to be taken.
Prescription medications are further divided into sub-categories:
controlled and non-controlled.
Controlled medications: These are prescription medications that
have been legally designated as “controlled substances”. Drug
control agencies have considered drugs in this category to have a
high potential for abuse.
Non-Controlled Medications: This includes all other prescription
drugs that do not appear on the list. This does not mean that
drugs not on the controlled list have no potential for abuse.
In order to administer psychotropic medication, there must be a
consent form signed by the parent or guardian, stating that
medications can be administered to their youth person.
Methodist Incident Reports (IR) –
IR dated 7/26/2025 indicated that Mother arrived to campus to
pick up Youth A, reviewed and signed the medication chain of
custody form and advised that she did not consent to listed
Dessmorpressin (DDAVP) medication. She also referred to the
medication as psychotropic medication. Incident report was
authored and signed by Supervisor.
IR dated 7/28/2025 indicated that mother advised Supervisor and
Therapist that she did not dispense prescribed medication
Dessmorpressin (DDAVP) because she did not consent to it.
Incident report was authored and signed by Supervisor.
Methodist Medication Chain of Custody Form- Form is dated
for 7/26/2025 and documents planned home visit for Youth A.
Five prescribed medications are listed for Youth A, including
Dessmorpressin (DDAVP). The name and dosage of each
medication is listed, along with RX number, instructions and count.
The form notes that medications were packaged by Supervisor.
The form also includes the signature of Mother acknowledging
receipt. Mother also wrote on the form that she did not consent to
Dessmorpressin (DDAVP).
MAR Record for Youth A – The form documented five prescribed
medications for Youth A. The prescribing physician, origination
date of prescription, Rx number and dosage instructions were
4

included on the form. All medications had been dispensed as
required through the print date of the MAR.
Video Review
There was no video footage available relative to the allegations.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance with the licensing rule. After review of agency
policy, interview with agency staff and prescribing physician and
review of youth MAR it was determined that the medication did not
require additional parental consent, and it was confirmed that
attempts were made to contact the parent for a medication review
without success.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(g) Methods for dispensing medication when the resident will be
off site.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation When parent was provided medication for overnight visit, the pill
packets were not labeled or in the original packaging.
Investigation Interviews
On 08/04/2025 and 08/28/2025 telephone calls were made to
Complainant without success. A voicemail message was left
requesting a return call.
On 08/05/2025 an in-person interview was completed with
Residential Manager 2 (RM 2) at Methodist, Area Manager was
also present. RM 2 confirmed that agency policy indicated that
when provided for overnight visits the container in which the
medication are provided is to be properly labeled with all
necessary medication to ensure proper administration. She
further admitted that the envelopes provided to Mother were not
labeled as indicated in the policy.
On 08/05/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Youth
A at Methodist, Area Manager was also present. He reported that
the envelope provided to Mother for his visit only had his name on
it and did not have other information.
5

On 08/05/2025 an in-person interview was completed with
Supervisor at Methodist, Area Manager was also present. She
reported in preparation for overnight visits for Youth A, his
medication was placed in individual envelopes. Supervisor
confirmed she packaged the medication but could not recall if all
required information was listed on the packaging.
Documentation Reviewed
Methodist Medication Policy - All containers in which prescription
medication’s are dispensed must have a label which contains, at
minimum, all of the following:
1. Pharmacy name, and address
2. Prescription number
3. Person’s name
4. Date the prescription was most recently dispensed
5. Prescribers name
6. Directions for use
7. Name of medication
8. Amount dispensed
9. Strength of medication
10. Dosage of medication
11. Any special instructions for storage or handling
Methodist Medication Chain of Custody Form- Form is dated
for 7/26/2025 and documents planned home visit for Youth A.
Five prescribed medications are listed for Youth A, including
Dessmorpressin (DDAVP). The name and dosage of each
medication is listed, along with RX number, Instructions and
Count. The form notes that medications were packaged by
Supervisor. The form also includes the signature of Mother
acknowledging receipt.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with the licensing rule. Interviews were
completed with agency staff and the agency policy was reviewed.
Agency staff admitted that medication for the overnight visit was
not packaged and labeled as required by agency policy.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
6

Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
